title: Central Park, New York City
address: 59th to 110th St., from Central Park West to 5th Ave., Manhattan Borough, New York City, NY 10022
review_list:
We visited with our 17 month old daughter on the 15th February. That weekend was the coldest in decades apparently and temperatures hit -1f (-18c) and we could feel it! It was very very cold! All the lakes were frozen solid and when it started to snow, it was amazing. I love this park!

So much going on, you could spend a full day in this park and be entertained. I was there on a Saturday morning and the atmosphere was fab.

I've always wanted to walk through Central Park during a snow day. Finally I got a chance to do enjoy this park. Definitely recommend to everyone

Love this park! It is far the best city park I have visited. Considering the size of the city, the park feels so peaceful. I love running there. One can also rent a bike.

Always charming in every season! I love just a short walk away and enjoy this park through all seasons of the year and just can't tell you which is the most beautiful!

Walked around Central Park twice during our visit. The first time it was -17 so it was a pretty short walk.
Second time we got a bit further. Very beautiful setting and felt very safe walking around it. Would love to check it out in Summer or Autumn.
Must see when in NYC 😁

Our hotel was so close to the park that we had to pop in. It was as busy as ever and although the snow had just gone the sun was shining and the vibe was lovely. As always there around people hassling you on the way in to ride the horse carriages or the tuc tuc bikes but once past...


More  



A must see if you visit New York, either by electric carriage or by horse and carriage. Take it with a tour guide as they are very knowledgeable about every area of this beautiful park, and all the celebs who live in appartments around the park..

Huge park , loads of things happening , worth hiring bike , carriage rides expensive, I think a spring/summer visit is best , and it's a long long walk !

We've been here many times and will continue to visit frequently when we come to NYC. There are always new and exciting acts to discover around the park and the people and dog watching could entertain anybody for hours. An absolute must for a visit to the city. Definitely worth enhancing the experience with 'Peter Pen's' bike tours - he...


More

title: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City
address: 1000 5th Ave, New York City, NY 10028-0198
review_list:
Fabulous architecture, great displays and more than enough stuff to keep you coming back. Its a very big place, so pace yourself.

This museum is always a treat to visit! Most of the museum days are pay as you like so not an expensive proposition for a budget tourist too! One of my favorite exhibits was the recent China through the looking glass!

We took an approved private tour of the museum that connected archaeological finds to the Bible. It was fascinating to make the connections. The admission price is only suggested but if you take a tour it is required.

It has a lot of exhibits. I don't really like art, but old Statues and temple from Egypt was still impressive.

Fairly expensive for a museum after being used to free entry to museums in UK. Brilliant 4th floor with Picasso Matisse and Van Gogh to name a few. Great for a rainy day.

Take your teenagers there - it will do them good.
Make sure to check ahead of time about special exhibits, movies and shows

Anyone who has an appreciation for art, architecture, history, fashion, design will find something they like here. It is great for kids, and adults as well. It is too much for one day. The best part is they have a "pay what you wish" policy. A must when in NYC.

We went to see the Van Gogh Iris collection on display and the China Fashion collection. This museum has a delightful roof top observation area - where you can enjoy champagne, beverages and nibbles, plus 2 other restaurants. Always enjoy our visit to this very large and comprehensive museum. Very serene outing.

Mesmerised by so many Rembrandts in one place and able to view them close up! Also no queuing and suggested donations on entry.

Set aside a good amount of time to truly enjoy every corner of this magnificent museum featuring some truly iconic artwork. Try to go in quiet times because it can become a little frustrating when one has to traverse big crowds taking millions of pictures.

title: Top of the Rock Observation Deck, New York City
address: 30 Rockefeller Center, New York City, NY
review_list:
Absolutely loved this. It was a beautiful sunny day so we could see for miles. Plenty of space to be able to see the 360* views without being blocked by other visitors. Also seating available if you need a rest or just want to sit and soak up the atmosphere. Staff very friendly and helpful. Very reasonable price for such...


More  



The view is amazing and would recommend to anyone to do this if your in New York.
You get a cracking view of the Empire state building and central park. And of you strain your eyes enough you can see the statue of Liberty.
I felt really safe and my fear of heights was put at ease.
If you download...


More  



great views from here, all sides and good pics available; love the elevator trip- look up! Bit of a muddle getting to the elevators on ground floor, but be patient.

I paid $45 for the Rock/MoMa combo. It was unbelievably cold during Valentine's weekend. But I had heard this was the best view of the city and it didn't disappoint! Go to the very, very top where you have unobstructed views without the glass. You can see Manhattan in every direction. I am an amateur photographer and it's an amazing...


More  



I have lived in New York all my life and never had been to the observation deck. Everything was well organized and the views are amazing. I'm so happy I could say I did this!!

For the best unobstructed views, this is a must visit. It's also worth paying a little extra to have professional photos taken at the top, they are really spectacular. If you can visit as the sun is setting, it's simply magical and well worth it. We will continue to begin every visit to the city with this attraction.

It's a little pricey (over $30 as of February 2016), but the views from the top are simply spectacular, and mostly unobstructed! You get a great view of the Empire State Building, Crysler Building, Central Park, Times Square, and the rest of Midtown. The top floors are open-air and provide amazing photo-taking opportunities. I highly recommend this attraction during any...


More  



Our first trip to New York and we did most of the "must see" while there. Top of the Rock is great. Amazing views. Go at sunset if you can.

This is a great place to take photos! You get an amazing view of central park and you actually get to see the city skyline with the empire state in it! There are three different platforms to explore and you can get combo tickets online with places like the Moma. I'd definitely recommend you book ahead to avoid the long...


More  



To think this is 80 years old and still one of NYC most prestigious and spectacular addresses. Cold and very windy but no queues made February a good time to visit

title: The National 9/11 Memorial & Museum, New York City
address: 180 Greenwich St, World Trade Center, New York City, NY 10007
review_list:
amazing day starting with the walking tour from St Pauls...you get the story first and then walk to the museum. Possible to spend hours and hours there; good movie tributes also as part of the experience.

This is a must what a beautiful way to remember the hero's and those poor innocent people who lost their lives on the fateful day. But it is very emotional so have your tissues ready

This Memorial and Museum is so well done. It is visually beautiful and educational. You enter by one of the pools and continue down to the foundations of one of the towers. You get a structural and emotional education of September 11th.
I was moved by the exhibits and artifacts.

Moving experience to see the memorial and view the museum. Allow plenty of time to get through the museum. It is worth it. We did this as part of our CityPass and so glad we made the time to go to that part of the city. Emotional experience.

Everything is incredibly well done and tastefully done. You can't help but be moved. It's a must see.

A moment in history that has defined and will continue to define America. A must see for young and old.The memorial is a reminder of the so many souls lost and should be explained to generations to come.

The memorial and museum were done very respectfully. The exhibits are very moving and pay great respect to those that lost their lives. This was my favorite museum we visited in New York.

We went in Feb during the week and there was no queue, and getting through security was very fast. It seems inappropriate to question the cost but it is a bit steep which could put people off going which would be a shame as everyone should have a chance to visit.
The building is well designed and the exhibits fascinating...


More  



I wasn't sure what to expect but it was very good. The way it was designed and how they tell you about it is great. Definitely worth visiting. We didn't do the museum as the wait was to long but just wondering around the grounds was very moving.

After a few film presentations head down to the foundations of the original towers. Here you can see personal stories about victims and also the history of the original north and south towers. In the foundations of the south tower is a harrowing exhibition about the events of that day. Film footage and artefacts. A sobering and moving experience. We...


More

title: Manhattan Skyline, New York City
address: New York City, NY
review_list:
I did a cruise to the Statue of Liberty and was able to see the skyline. It looks awesome during the day and can only imagine what it would look like at night. Definitely worth the view

It is very nice to look at lower Manhattan skyline. We did this from Statue of Liberty island, Ellis island, Staten Island ferry at night and day. Would really suggest it.

We took the boat to Ellis Island & Statue of Liberty and while your on the boat can look at the Manhattan Skyline and see the new One World Tower it looks fantastic

New York is a must see for everyone once in their lifetime and I guarantee you will have seen the Manhattan Skyline at some time in the past an will recall the film or TV show you saw it on. Don't miss a view of the skyline from the ferry over to Ellis Island.

Amazing site to see and take pictures of when flying in. Totally breathtaking. Ready to go back already!!

Amazing views of the skyline on the water taxi. Breath taking during the day and I'm sure at night as well. The architecture is amazing.

great views, seen in daylight from Brooklyn Bridge, Staten Island ferry and Empire State Building at night

I love the skyline but for me the best skyline is from the Staten ferry on the return trip. Skyline is great from all the observation points like ESB but I think the full majesty is from the water or on Brooklyn bridge.

The cool think about this is that you can see it from New Jersey! There are several locations to see it from!

When returning on the Staten Island Ferry we were dazzled by the lit up skyline. It is a breathtaking view.

title: Broadway, New York City
address: New York City, NY
review_list:
No trip to New York but to be complete without a visit to Broadway, particularly the area from 40th Street to 45th Street, such an amazing atmosphere and so much to do, it's worth queueing at TKTS for an official reduced price Broadway theatre ticket, not to mention the bright lights of times square and a trip to juniors for...


More  



It's bright, it's crowded it's Broadway!!! Go see a show if your budget will allow. It's fun, it's fabulous, it's loud and bright. It's one hell of an experience.

Razzle Dazzle!!! A high energy, talented cast wowed us with great singing and dancing! We were so excited to discover the talented Paige Davis in the role of Roxie. And the Chicago orchestra kept our feet tapping throughout the show.

Highly recommend seeing "Les Misérables" as well as "On Your Feet! The Story of Emilio & Gloria Estefan". Two very different shows but each show is fantastic.

Great place to visit and see lots of different things. Spent New Years on Broadway with a ton of other people and it was lots of fun. Definitely have to visit if you're in New York.

Great show with only 6 cast members! Lots of stairs to manage in mezzanine so if you have someone that is stair challenged please sit in orchestra seats. No intermission so do potty before you are seated. Worth seeing !

Broadway runs from Uptown to Downtown Manhattan and there is something for everyone. It is a fascinating walk (not the complete length!) just to get a feel of the different districts it passes through. The area near the theaters and Times Square is lively and busy and really felt like the New York you imagine 'the city that never sleeps'....


More  



Visited during the day & late evening. Best at night the lights wow! we were there on Valentines day couples were getting married inside a ring of large yellow hearts fabulous. a must see in New York.

Another iconic place to visit and take in a show or just walk around looking at the great theatre's and walking in the footsteps of legends that have walked around over time here.

There is so many lights to take in. So much to eat and see. Many crazy people dancing around on the streets and small street vendors selling goods. Highly recommend taking a trip down.

title: The High Line, New York City
address: New York City, NY 10014
review_list:
What a lovely walk on a Saturday afternoon! It's about 20 city blocks long (so, about a mile), with lots of beautiful views, plantings and interesting new buildings surrounding it. Highly recommended and a must for New York City visitors. Word of caution: tends to get really crowded on summer weekends, so, plan your visit accordingly.

You can buy coffee/ tea/ a snack room Chelsea market and take it with you for a stroll on the Higgins highline going north.

This is a trip worth taking, a pleasant walk away from the traffic. The views are really good & it's a great way to see this part of the city.

Nice walk w glimpses of true NY, for now. Go very early, gets packed. Start or end at BilllyMarks for a cold beer uptown or Gansevoort market for light lunch (and bathroom break).

We walked the High Line after doing the Circle Line water tour. It was a long walk back but we really enjoyed it. It was busy and there are a couple places you can stop for a beverage or treat but on a sunny day I would suggest bringing a bottle of water.

If you have an hour or 2, spend walking the Highline. It can be quite relaxing and fun to people watch.

Gets so crowded on weekend afternoons. Avoid it at that time, seriously! We brought egg sandwiches up with us on a weekday morning and had a lovely breakfast.

My husband and I loved our experience of the High Line. Great energy and a fun place to be within the city. Also has easy access to the Chelsea Market, which was amazing.

Take the Highline walk and see New York City and river views from a very different perspective. A winter day was sunny, cold, but between the buildings, one could even take a rest on the wooden lounge chairs on the walk. Great people watching with the illusion of being in the thick of things, while above it all.

The High Line was fun to walk along. It was covered in snow while we were there but offered great views of Jersey and the Hudson. It's nice, but not as groundbreaking as it pretends to be.

title: Grand Central Terminal, New York City
address: 89 E 42nd Street, New York City, NY 10017
review_list:
Called into Grand Central Station and have to say it's such a lovely building. Lots of people milling around and from the decor to the painted ceilings, it's just beautiful.
I can see why people choose to propose here.
Check it out

We always have to come and take in the sights of grand central. It's so iconic and we always feel slightly overwhelmed at its atmosphere. The food hall and shops dotted around the building make for an interesting hour or two if you want to make a bigger visit of it. A must visit for NYC.

This building is worth just going into and walking around. After the renovation, all the spectacular features are much better appreciated. There is also a very famous place to eat there....definitely worth it particularly for the seafood lover. It is the Oyster Bar.

Worth a trip to see the incredible central ticket hall, absolutely stunning building. Foodcourt downstairs has some good options but can be a little pricey and crowded

This is another of those must see places in New York and we went both at night and during the day. In daytime it is very busy and your photo's will show how busy but we also went at around 8pm and as it was much quieter you could get better pictures of the architechture as well as having to...


More  



This building is just gorgeous, the roof is spectacular and the place seems so familiar having seen it in so many films and tv programmes. Well worth a visit

Grand Central Terminal is a very nice building. We had a free self guided tour so extra knowledge makes it more interesting.

It's troubling to think that GCT came this close to suffering the same fate as the original Pennsylvania Station. But thanks to a group of well connected citizens back in the 60's, it was saved in perpetuity (we hope) for all to see and marvel at. The Main Concourse is simply splendid, most likely the most beautiful working transportation hub...


More  



We visited Grand Central on several occasions during our trip, even during a power cut. The place is spotless and blows you away when you walk in, no matter how busy it gets it just remains calm and safe. The staff once again are friendly and polite and helpful, the police officers are exactly the same and are willing to...


More  



Interesting to see this building. We were there during a power cut so didn't get to see it in all its glory. Grand building, vast but busy.

title: Frick Collection, New York City
address: 1 E. 70th St., Fifth Ave., New York City, NY 10021
review_list:
The Frick Museum is a "blow your socks off" collection of art. Quite simply: If you are visiting New York City, go to this museum. An impressive collection of Turners, Constable, Vermeer, Holbein and more, and beautiful entire room paintings by Fragonard. The house reminded me of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, complete with a beautiful courtyard at...


More  



Beautiful collections at the Frick, the art the home and the history are stunning. This is a favorite place to visit. Great for solo travelers and couples seeking a peaceful stroll through a museum,

Savor the Frick slowly, and between the diffrent room, sit around its courtyard and enjoy the peaceful feeling this jewel imparts.

I have visited NYC many times but somehow or another I have never gone to Frick even though I wanted to. It was wonderful. We went when it was cold (0) and windy so no so many folks as I would imagine it has normally. Well arranged, great art, furniture, accessories and the building itself is a masterpiece. Did bring...


More  



The Frick Collection reminds me of the Gardner Museum (without the restrictions on placement and additions). Beautiful buildings and grounds (would like to see the grounds in the spring rather than dead of winter). Be sure to sit through the 15ish minute film on Mr. Frick, the building and his art collection

Portraits and paintings by Rembrandt and Vermeer along with several by English painters. Nice collection of carvings, sculptures, and pottery as well. Located at corner of 5th avenue and 70th street adjacent to Central Park. Audio guides available to supplement your experience.

My friends and I spent about three hours in the museum. It is the house that clearly reflected the personality and preferences of the owner: his idea was to surround himself with beautiful pieces of art. Even the women in the paintings were attractive. The only problem I had was the lack of benches in every hall.

Tourists always head to the big three museums, MOMA, Metropolitan, and Natural History. Each great and vast. For a less overwhelming museum experience, nothing beats the Frick. A modestly sized collection of astonishing quality and significance, housed in the grand turn-of-the-century Frick mansion on upper east side. You won't be crushed by tour bus crowds at the Frick. All together...


More  



A bit disappointed to be honest, it was a bit like going around a country home at home (UK), but with the States being a bit younger (and I do not mean that to sound patronising) I can see how the history of the items appeal to Americans. Lovely courtyard entrance hall. With regard to the question about recommending to...


More  



Beware...Sunday afternoon visit results in a lot of people as the exhibit fee is by donation from 11-1. Did not know this and would have preferred less crowds. Beautiful mansion and quite a collection of art!

title: Empire State Building, New York City
address: 350 Fifth Avenue, Between 33rd and 34th Streets, New York City, NY 10118
review_list:
Once you are in the building you have to walk a long way to eventually get to the elevator, they have you going round and round endless roped off pathways! Still we got to the top eventually and it was definitely worth it. We went at night so we could see the lights, it was bitterly cold up there so...


More  



The Empire State building offers unrivalled views over the NYC skyline, it's a must for any weekenders to the city, if not just for the views but for the experience of going somewhere so iconic in so many ways, books, film, television etc. However be prepared to pay for it with your time. Each step of the journey to the...


More  



How can anyone refuse a trip to the top of the Empire State Building where parts of the movie An Affair To Remember were filmed. From the top you can see all of Manhatten and it's suburbs as well as New Jersey, Hudson River complete with the Statue of Liberty or the George Washington Bridge. When in New York, a...


More  



Enjoyed the Empire State building and not just the view from the top. Take the time to read the information and see the pictures inside as they are so informative. Amazing would they did back then putting together a structure such as this. Once you get to the top it can be busy but it is so worth it. Make...


More  



We visited this by both day and night to see the difference. At night the city does look quite interesting and certainly times square stands out more due to the electronic billboards, however we thought that the daytime trip was more worthwhle as we really were able to make out far more of the iconic landmarks in daylight ( and...


More  



I visited during my first trip to NY. I felt I had to! I went late afternoon and by the time I got to the observation deck it was dark. The night time views were fabulous but the deck was super busy. If I return to New York (sorry.... WHEN I return to New York 😉) I don't think I...


More  



We wanted to go to the top and it was a 4 hour wait. We talked to some locals and they recommended Top of the Rock for better views and no wait so check around before waiting in line all day. The building definitely looks cool but as mentioned check around before going to the top.

Viewing the city from the 86th floor is really worth doing! (Even for someone who doesn't like heights!!) The day we visited was snowy and very cold but didn't ruin the views!
A must in NYC!
The audio guide is interesting too to help learn about the making of the famous building. Really worth picking up the headphones and iPod!...


More  



After reading history of Empire State building, it was very interesting to actually get on top and appreciate the views of Manhattan. We have been there at night, as it closes at 2am

I wouldn't say that it's a must when visiting NYC but if you have an hour or two to kill I'd recommend visiting. The lines are expectedly longer, but everything goes smooth and is actually faster than you'd expect considering the number of people. The view is definitely worth the wait. Again, if you have time you could spend it...


More

title: Bryant Park, New York City
address: between 40th and 42nd Streets & Fifth and Sixth Ave, New York City, NY 10017
review_list:
Tons of shops, eats, but majority is great shops you can find at home. For example, yoga gear, ornaments (which anyone in Cleveland will write NYC as long as you are paying), I do recommend 'Fifth and Madison' home fragrances. Great packaging and scent without wallet busting. Otherwise, go skate or eat and move on. Definite bonus-cleanest public bathroom in...


More  



We weren't going to go here as it seemed out of our way but we are definitely glad we did. We actually went 3 times during our stay it was so good. From the restaurants, little shops and skating rink it is a great place. Definitely worth the visit!!

If you go over the Christmas period Bryant Park has a free ice skating rink. All the others charge ( Central Park, Rockefeller etc). Lovely Christmas stalls selling food, mulled cider, and artisan crafts. We just enjoyed watching the nuns skate!

Bryant Park for ice skating is great alternative to the Rockefeller Rink and a fraction of the price.
The Rink is available from start of Nov until March.
Would recommend the Fast Pass tickets giving speedy access, quicker time to your stakes no being on the rink.
It can be busy at times and with the rink not being huge,...


More  



You get very little for free but this very large outdoor rink was free if you had your own skates and only $15 to hire skates. The staff were welcoming and the ice was well looked after skated for about two hours a very enjoyable time

This is a must-see any time of year. In the summer, it's a great place to hang out and grab a meal (or get a shake across the street and enjoy it in the park). In the winter, take in the skating rink and the Christmas shops. Grab a hot chocolate or a warm Belgian waffle to keep you warm!...


More  



Bryant park is one of my favorite places in NYC. There's always something special going on - from skating to a French weekend with booths for purchasing anything you might want. It's surrounded by great places to grab a bite, and is right near Grand Central and Times Square.

We watched the skaters for a wile. Brightly lit and festive looking. Little penguins as aides for kids learning to skate.

Winter time there is the winter village with ice skating, food, artisan crafts, and beautiful Xmas tree. So I recommend checking it out but it's also a nice spot in the summer to gather with friends.

Nothing special here, not as grand as central park but there is an ice rink which is a novelty, wouldn't go out of my way to return.

title: Radio City Music Hall, New York City
address: 1260 6th Avenue (Avenue of the Americas), Between 50th and 51st Streets, New York City, NY 10020
review_list:
I was very impressed with the Radio City Rockettes Christmas show. The production was the best I have seen there. I was pleased I did not pass this up.

We visited Radio City Hall while in the city on holiday, and it's like a tardis it just opens up and wow it's very impressive, the tour was great and very informative and we had our photo taken with one of the famous " Rocketts" This place is well worth a visit.

The theatre is beautiful and the dancing and customs make for a fun treat but honestly there is so much talent on Broadway I would not do this more than once....I would go to the theatre for that special treat!

Was not sure what to expect but wow what a great show. My 12 year old granddaughter was thrilled with the performances . Very much worth the time and cost of tickets.

It is definitely worth going to see the Rockettes perform during christmas time at least once in your life. It truly is a lovely spectacle, but it is quite repetitive after that. This pertains more to the performance than the location. The venue is very vibrant and has some good staff and others who are rough and rude.

What a great place to visit when your in New York. Iconic building from the outside and once your inside it just keeps getting better.

We took the VIP trip around the iconic Radio City Music Hall. So glad we did! We were able to go up on the main stage and behind the scenes to see the hydraulics for stage operation. We also toured the Rockettes rehearsal studios and even met a real Rockette. The building is so beautiful and the history is really...


More  



We took part in the Radio City backstage tour. Our guide (Alvin) was informative, knowledgeable, polite and couteous. The tour itself takes you into the iconic theatre, behind the scenes, under the stage, to the top floor. The beautiful theatre is a true masterpiece. As part of the tour we also got to meet on of the famous Rockettes in...


More  



Overtime I visit NYC doing the Christmas Holiday I make sure I buy a ticket for their Christmas Spectacular show that together with the great acoustic they have in Radio City Music Hall is a must.
The theater itself is a show in itself with the red velvet upholstery and the entrance chandelier

If in NY at Christmas time a visit to Radio City to see the iconic Rockettes is an absolute must! Great show for the whole family. Didn't really need to see it again this year as it doesn't really change, however, there we were ... for our third visit over the past six years. I still enjoyed the experience.

title: Ground Zero Museum Workshop, New York City
address: 420 West 14th Street, Floor 2, New York City, NY 10014
review_list:
Unbelievable place. Such a beautiful memorial to all those people that tragically lost their lives. I was so overwhelmed it made me cry. Would definitely recommend this place. The museum itself is actually underground in the original Twin Towers footings.

The GZ Museum Workshop allows visitors to see never before seen photos of ground zero. It also tells viewers the story behind these photos. We were able to touch real steal and glass from the twin towers. It was an unforgettable experience

This was certainly not what we anticipated; it was far better. This tiny, studio-sized museum is very interactive and very moving, especially to people from the tri-state area or affected by 9/11 directly.

The 911 museum was breath taking. To see all the
artifacts that were saved, pictures of firemen saving
people, videos, everything was very emotional. To see
all there things brought back instantly feelings of that day the towers wet down. Don't miss this site, well worth the effort it may take to get there.
BUY TICKETS ahead of time...ticket lines...


More  



This museum displays artefacts from the tragedy including parts of the aeroplane which hit the twin towers, damaged fire engine, original missing people posters, good bye recordings from people who knew they weren't going to make it out alive and the events as told by the emergency services, all paint a picture of tragedy together with true heroics. This is...


More  



fun memorable and educational
he made things to bring home and show his class teacher and friends. great idea for the children

This is completely separate from the actual 9/11 site, which is where we went initially, only to be told out was several blocks away, we should have read the instructions! When we did get there, it's a doorway on a main shopping street near the highline. You have to press a bell to get in. We had a really interesting...


More  



We showed up just as Trey was closing for the day but he still allowed us to walk in and spend an amazing couple of hours in this seemingly hidden gem of a museum. Stunning photography and some artifacts that move you beyond belief. These are coupled with the story behind each and every one told by Gary in your...


More  



As someone who spent 30 years in law enforcement, this is a must place to visit when in the city. You will need a good 3 hours to see and read everything from that day in history. Very sobering experience of reality, done very well on one of the worst events to happen in history.

Very impressive touring this Museum underground and seeing all the items collected from this horrible tragedy. Take the Subway for the complete New York Experience..

title: Statue of Liberty, New York City
address: Liberty Island, New York City, NY 10004
review_list:
Okay so I did go in the middle of summer but it was crazy hot and humid and I live in Florida. I would suggest just staying on the ferry and skipping Ellis Island all together. I was so disappointed to find that most of the artifacts were at another location due to a previous hurricane they had experienced. The...


More  



We went on the free Ranger led tour and it was wonderful. It involves more standing than walking, but you could potentially sit on one of the low walls or benches if you are unable to stand for a long time. The amount of history we learned in that tour was amazing. I thought I knew about the Statue of...


More  



Good day out.
Statue of Liberty and Ellis island takes about 4-5 hours in total. Really interesting and the audio guides are great.

Thoroughly enjoyed our boat trip over to Liberty. Island and very impressive the statue is too. This is such an iconic part of New York that you must make time to see.

The trip to the crown of the Statue of Liberty was one of the highlights of our trip to New York. You have to buy the tickets 3-4 months in advance, so plan ahead. Also, you cannot take anything but water and your phone to the top, but you can rent a secure locker for $2.00. You can take an...


More  



Had to see the Grand Lady that many had seen when seeking a new country
We had a water taxi the Skipper was a knowledgeable guide to the harbour
Fantastic photo opportunity to be close up to this wonderful New York Landmark
We enjoyed out on the harbour on this private boat however if you are on a budget the...


More  



Very good value and very well organised. Got the staten island ferry booked online the same day no hassle. Easy to find in battery Park. Self guided tour. Really impressive up close.
Having been to New York before and gotten boat trips around it. It really is soooo worth getting off and really experiencing it. Great views of the NY...


More  



We didn't want to wait in line so found Hornblower Cruise and they get you right beside the island. You don't get off the boat but you get great views from the boat and it's definitely worth doing the cruise vs going to the island. The only reason to go to the island is if you can walk to the...


More  



What an amazing day out for the whole family. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit and would recommend everyone to visit this beautiful symbols of American freedom

We were very glad that we took a ferry to the Statue of Liberty and Ellis island. Audio tour of the statue and Ellis island museum gave a whole new dimension for the experience! All the history and stories makes it even more wonderful

title: Rockefeller Center, New York City
address: 45 Rockefeller Plaza, New York City, NY 10111
review_list:
At the same price as the Empire State building ( observation deck only) this offers three floors of views with the very top floor not being obstructed by plastic barriers to stop you jumping !. You get a far better view of Central park here than at ESB and of course a good view of the ESB. There is nowhere...


More  



We were visiting during New Years and went to Rockefeller Center a few times. It is definitely a happening place but very packed. You have to visit it as least once and if you like skating, try it out but book in advance to get a spot otherwise you'll wait for a long time.

I love Rockefeller center especially during Christmas. I went once and thought it was beyond beautiful. I will never go again just because there are thousands of people and I'm not a people's person. I highly recommend visiting any time because it's a beautiful place. If you're in NYC around the holidays definitely stop by and check the tree out...


More  



A group of us visited the Rockefeller in February and we had a great time. The views from the top of the rock were ones we will never forget. We then went on to the tour which was great lead by Aaron. I would definitely recommend going to the top for those breathtaking views and then onto the tour to...


More  



Great place to visit, loads of things to do and see. Don't miss all the shops on the lower ground level. Go ice skating and travel to the top for great views over the city.

It's a fun experience to ice skate during Christmas time. We had a blast the only thing is it is quite expensive and overpriced for the experience.

This was an interesting place to visit. Lots to see and do including the famous ice rink. We visited as we joined a standby queue to be in the audience of a tapping of the late show with Jimmy Falon. There are various places to eat and different types of shops. Worth a visit even if its just for a...


More  



Part of the American soft power is its ability to export every day sights to all parts of the world - and Rockefeller Centre is one of those buildings that one immediately associates with New York so even though I have been here many times before, j still had to come back again. One can say it's just a shopping...


More  



We took the hour long Rockefeller tour which ledges through and around several of the building that make up Rockefeller Plaza. This included passing the Cathedral, NBC studios, Radio City Music Hall, Atlas, the ice rink and the site of the famed Christmas Tree.
The tour guide was charismatic and knowledgable.She provided us with radio headsets so we didn't miss...


More  



This is just a great scene. Tons of people skating and the entire place is buzzing. Definitely a place to walk by and visit if you are in town.

title: Staten Island Ferry, New York City
address: 4 South Street, New York City, NY 10004
review_list:
Quite a nice way to see Manhattan, and the Statue Of Liberty from the water for free. Avoid going during busy commuter hours because it gets really busy.

Very nice attraction. Sadly we were not able to go to the nicest parts of ferry as weather was cold and it was closed. Views of Manhattan and Liberty statue are really nice

Make sure you goto the right ferry terminal, Staten island ferry is free. but while you walk there , there will be hustlers and posters trying to direct you to the private cruise. once on board, stay at the back of the ferry. it has open space you can take as many pics as you like and enjoy the great...


More  



Free! Convenient. Great skyline views. This does not get close to Statue of Liberty. But you can see her. It was a nice break and a different way to see the city. Would do again and recommend. The dock is surrounded by people trying to sell you tried to see her, but we just kept saying no thank you and...


More  



This free ferry service is only a short subway ride from Manhattan and gives a wonderful perspective of NYC from another angle. The views are fantastic, especially if you board one of the ferries with an outside deck. The ferry service is very efficient and well run and I can't believe it is free!

Free ferry trip with great views of Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island and the Manhatten skyline. Approximately 25 minutes each way. Can stop and have a drink at Staten Island Ferry Station and catch the next one back. They go every half an hour. Beware of the people trying to sell you tickets to see the Statue at the entrance...


More  



See a great view of New York and the statue of liberty and all for free. The staff told us the best place to stand to get the best view,took loads of pictures.

We took the ferry over to Staten Island as a way of viewing the Statue of Liberty without paying crazy prices for private tour boats. The ferry is completely free!! The ferries are frequent so you don't have to wait around to long for one. The only thing to note is that you're not allowed to stay on board if...


More  



This ride is free so my tip if you are going to do it and have some extra time do it at night you will get the best views of the city and the statue of liberty

A local man we talked to by drinking coffee gave us this hint on the staten island ferry round trip. It takes you a bit more than 1 hours to do a releaxed three round trip and watching the skyline and statue of liberty. You should ignore the guys who want to sell you trips to the statue, etc.

title: One World Observatory - World Trade Center, New York City
address: 1 World Trade Center, One World Trade Center, New York City, NY 10007
review_list:
great finish to the 911 tour. see the magic of Manhattan all around. Friendly staff at the top and good snacks also.

We went on Sunday morning the weekend after Valentines Day - the quietest weekend in New York. We got tickets in advance online. No wait. Very well managed and brilliantly presented elevator ride up and unveiling of the view. Spectacular view. Better than Empire State according to our traveling companions who have done both. Bravo.

This is a must do when visiting the city, the very speedy lifts takes you up to the 80th floor in seconds and then you change to another and you climb more floors to the observation level and the view hits you immediately, the panorama is breathtaking and a camera is a must to catch all those lovely images.

Amazing views, cool building, even the elevator ride up is entertaining. Nice to visit on a clear sunny day.

It's not until you get up to it you realise just how big it is. Well worth a trip up to the top but expect long queues.

Well worth the money. Awesome views. 360 degree views. Go for sure when in New York city, so much history there and breath taking views.

Such a great experience. The elevator ride up is thrilling. The view is beautiful. The friendly staff was all very hospitable and classy. It seemed like we were being treated to a high class resort. Very clean and elegant looking. One lady told us this is a popular spot for marriage proposals. I can see how it would be considered...


More  



We did not have to queue for very long and the views from the top were breath taking to save money pre book with the likes of Aviator and save about $10 if your in New York this is one that you must visit

Wow! When you first see the view, it takes your breath away. My daughter and I filled up we were that blown away. Fabulous experience.

The observation deck is great and if you have to choose between this and any other building, go here. The views of the harbor are unparalleled. The elevator ride alone is worth the trip--watch the walls... (just take Dramamine for the ride back down!!). The view is better than the Empire State Building and the deck is less crowded, making...

title: New York Public Library, New York City
address: 476 5th Ave New York, NY 10018, New York City, NY 10018
review_list:
I thought it was going to be an actual library(or a section with a library) but it's more of a museum. They offer tours(didn't look into them) and there are lots of places to roam around and check out. The architecture of the building is great.

I've walked by the library dozens of times, today I had a few minutes for a quick visit to see the reading rooms, exhibits, art, architecture. It did not disappoint. Next time I'll spend more time looking at the statutes and art which is displayed throughout the building. The reading rooms were interesting. Highlight this time was the photography exhibits....


More  



It is one of the most amazing places in all of New York City. The amount of information stored in this place is nuts. You literally find whatever you want. I highly recommend stopping by even if you're not a reader and just exploring the entire facility. There is nothing like it in the entire world. You can literally feel...


More  



Came to visit Pooh as we always do when in New York but he wasn't there and neither were Poohs friends. We asked the ladies at security and they said he was on a long vacation till the fall! Still a magnificent place to visit while in New York.

nice place to visit, but it would be better if you are in a guided visit. Unfortunately the famous room (seen from many films) is under renew, so, it is closed probably this entire year...

Check the schedule before you go. It's closed on Sundays. It also has been closed at other times. You really need to see the Public Reading Room. Spend a few minutes enjoying a book here along with hundreds of other people. What a great, big room!

I was excited to show my teenage daughters the NY Public Library and couldn't wait to see the Rose Main Reading Room. I was disappointed to see that the reading room is closed for restoration until next year. However, I certainly understand the need to repair this jewel of the NYPL. The building is beautiful and worth a peak inside.

Free entry to a beautiful library. You will be searched on entering but you are allowed to take photos. Lovely building.

Interesting building, worth a look and located close to Grand Central station too. Not sure I'd return!

Spent some time here on very cold day in new york.. kids loved it - beautiful architecture. Would visit again

title: The Cloisters, New York City
address: 99 Margaret Corbin Drive, Fort Tryon Park, New York City, NY 10040
review_list:
This is a nice visit north of the city on the Hudson river. An easy drive from our hotel on the upper east side. Nice collection of salvaged Gothic archways, statues and icons from Italy, France and Spain. I enjoyed the maze like walk around the exhibits. A beautiful park and museum.

The scenery is what makes the Cloisters so attractive. Try going during the spring when the trees and plants are in bloom. Definitely worth your while. The Cloisters and in Fort Tryon park and travel time, if coming from Manhattan can be fairly long, believe I took the 1 train north to somewhere in the 200s...relatively easy to find. There...


More  



very beautiful, and peaceful, great if you like museums. must see especially in the summer. takes you straight back into another time

Not of a most popular attraction, because it is not in the city center but it is a beautiful place and worth a visit. Quiet and relaxing

The main treasure of the collection of 15th century counted tapestries from the series "Hunting at the Unicorn." They are impressive.

After a while, the city is so loud and busy. We wanted something a little quieter and different. It's a short train ride and a short walk through a park and all of a sudden we were in this medieval structure looking up at these huge unicorn tapestries. I don't know what exhibit is there now, but just to see...


More  



I just loved visiting this spot! It is in Fort Tyron Park in Upper Manhattan and a visit here will transport you to Medieval Europe. Be sure to arrive early as the ticket entrance here is also usable for the Met, so you should visit here in the AM, have lunch and then head to the Upper East Side to...


More  



Love the place! unique environment, great location in the park on the high bank of the Hudson River and a unique collection from cloisters of Europe.

We walked up the hill and up the stairs into the beautiful Cloisters, wandered around taking in the atmosphere and lingered in the gardens. So beautiful, peaceful and reflective.
Staff were wonderful and attentive (I was on crutches).
The cafe is a tremendous let down.... museums like these need the best local cuisine at affordable prices but high quality .......


More  



We enjoyed the walk from the Fort Tryon park subway station to the museum. The view in winter was very beautiful and a perfect emotional preparation for the calm museum. There are Christian artifacts here that really express the early reverence for Christ. The sculpture of Jesus on the cross are inspiring. The cloister columns are fascinating. This is a...

title: Madison Square Garden, New York City
address: 4 Penn Plaza, New York City, NY 10001

Great venue. Tons of food and drink, easily accessed. Nothing gluten free. $10 beers . Nice staff.
Good sight lines . Arrived too early and it was empty, cool in a way.

I was there to attend a college basketball match and the organization was good.
The only con is that there is less food option for the half time time out than the barclays center but it is ok.

Iconic Sporting Venue New York in a word WOW was very lucky to get ticket at box office for the local grudge match New York Rangers V New Jersey Devils ice hockey
Since a young age my bucket list was to go to the Gardens and was not disappointed fantastic to see the Rangers win the Atmosphere was great
The...

Just amazing to see such an iconic building and to understand some of the historic sporting and music events that have happened there

Our family attended the last night of the Westminster Dog Show. The facility is very clean and the staff were extremely accommodating. What an experience!

Even not being into the sport, seeing one of the greatest arenas and the behind the scenes areas was beyond incredible! With a very enthusiastic tour guide, we managed to learn about the stellar events that have happened at Madison Square Garden and its wonderful history. We got to see the player's changing rooms, got to see the court from...


More  



Make sure to catch ANYTHING at the garden. A game, a show, a concert, any event. The crowd truly represents what NY is about. Food and drinks WAY overpriced of course, so eat before. Right on top of Penn Station so expect tons of crowds.

Just attended the WKC Dog show, after being at MSG for dozens and dozens of concerts and a few sporting events ..a great venue, of course having the video screens helps when you are sitting far up....convenient to the subway...my main complaint is with the price of th concessions, but that's the situation everywhere.

Went on all access tour - locker rooms closed due to game at night but saw the teams practice on the ice. kids loved it. Went to match at night. Excellent night out

Easy access. Very central. Great variety. One of the iconic landmarks of NYC! Public transport seems the best way to get there.

title: St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York City
address: 460 Madison Avenue, New York City, NY 10022
review_list:
We didn't go in but looked around the outside and what a place. It is definitely worth walking by to view the architecture.

A must see in new York. So much history. I was there a year ago. It's completely renovated now. And stay for the church service too.

I had to go and see st.pats again , I was in it when I was 17yrs old and this trip was for my 50th , so times certainly had changed and I felt it , security men in the cathedral was now a normal thing , understandable so after 2011, but still I managed a quiet prayer , it...


More  



We attended an easter mass and it was very solemn. The structure of the church is outstanding. They have religious small items for sale also. Bring cash, they sell rosaries and stuff. I suggest every Catholic who comes to the city to visit this place.

Whether you are catholic or not - it's well worth the visit to St. Patrick's on 5th Avenue - across from the Rockefeller Center. There's no charge to enter and you can walk along the sides of the entire perimeter of the cathedral or you can sit at a pew and enjoy the serenity. My wife and I went on Ash Wednesday and the cathedral was very busy with people waiting to have the sign of the cross on their foreheads. Choir was singing and the whole scene was so calming. More  



Beautiful place of worship with a touch of technology. Sat in the back one Sunday for service. Not huge.

So beautiful and big inside. The architecture of the building is amazing and the upkeep is gorgeous.

I had the pleasure to be in mass at the Cathedral while in NY. It is a great experience and if you are catholic you should reserve your Sunday morning to go there. My advise is that you go in the 10:15 mass because I went in the 9:00 mass and it is quick and less impressive.

More  



When you walk into the cathedral, you feel like you're in Europe. The architecture is reminiscent of Westminster Abby in London. The stain glass is also worth the trip. Check it out and light a candle before you go. It can't hurt.

title: Times Square, New York City
address: Broadway, New York City, NY 10036
review_list:
here during the Big Snow Storm, it was still exciting to see the hardy buskers, wanderers, busy workers and tourists. All the lights, sounds, magic and mystery you have heard about all your life...

One cannot go to NYC without passing through times square at the very least. We were slightly disappointed on our most recent visit that so many roadworks/construction seemed to be happening. Naturally this needs to be done, but it dampened our experience slightly.

A must see when you are in NYC. Take it in during the day, then return at night for a different perspective.

We went to Time Square during the afternoon. It was crazy busy, construction going on and I was just not that impressed. I am sure it is cooler in the evening but maybe I was expecting more.

I live 45 min away from NYC so I'm kind of over Times Square. Every time I go to the city I usually pass by there and I don't see anything special about it anymore. If you're visiting NYC for the first time then it's another story. Definitely stop by, it's beautiful. Very crowded during certain times and events but...


More  



This is definitely a must if you're in New York. There are tons of people and lots going on but a great place to sit back and watch everything. I was there for New Years and it was a fun place. Definitely worth the visit.

Times square looks very nice at night, but I didn't see anything really spectacular. I would say it is slightly overrated.

A sight to be seen with all of the brightly lit screens and high rise buildings overhead. Lots of shops but not many places to eat on the square in winter as too cold to sit outside.

I stayed in a loft a block away and I have to say I didn't want to leave. Ever!!!! It's really all that and a bag of chips!

Another must visit place in the day and especially in the evening - just sit and absurd the atmosphere or pop into a multitude of restaurants - kept getting attracted back here each evening to get caught up in the hustle and bustle of New York. LAPD guys were great, taking time to talk to the kids and have photographs...

title: Tenement Museum, New York City
address: 103 Orchard Street, Lower East Side, New York City, NY 10002
review_list:
A fantastic view of immigrant history and New York History and American history. They do a great job of telling the history of the Lower East Side from the 1800s to the present. My only complaints are that you have to take all the tours to see it all and photos aren't allowed. However, we will make it a point...


More  



This was our second time visiting the Tenement Museum. Both times, we enjoyed very informative and interesting tours. The museum really helps you understand what it was like to be an immigrant in the early 1900s and appreciate what we live like today. I would recommend this experience to anyone who loves learning about New York's history!

We visited the Tenement Museum on Sunday Feb 21 2016. Once a month they have people act as the people who lived in the tenement on orchard street. You act as a reporter and ask the family members who were living in the tenement about their life there. it is excellent and the actors playing the family are first rate...


More  



If you have time and you are on the Lower East Side I highly recommend one of the tours here. I highly recommend booking in advance. A unique look back in history.

Best $25 spent in NYC. Fascinating, up close and personal. Our tour "educator" was so knowledgeable and really set the mood. These stories need to be shared and understood!

This is a refreshing change from the typical museum visit. There are several walking tours. We did "Outside the Home" and enjoyed it very much. We covered locations across several blocks and our guide was interesting and informative. It's invigorating taking a tour amongst the hustle and bustle of passing pedestrians and traffic. Try to show up early and watch...


More  



Perhaps it was out particular animator, but we left feeling like there was a lack of connection with today's immigrant life happening two blocks away on the other side of Delancey. The building and preservation is a great piece of history, but the hyperbolic reference to "how could people live like this" and "imagine all of these people living in...


More  



We took the Hard Times Tour having booked it about a week in advance. It was very worthwhile. The tour groups are very small (about a dozen people) because the space within the tenements is so small. It was a combination of social history,genealogy, and architectural history. The tour guide was excellent. There is a first rate film which I...


More  



Now, more than ever, it is important for we of European descent to see the Tenement Museum. The museum is an actual tenement built in 1863 and condemned in 1936. The museum has gathered the ancestries of those who lived in this building and the stories are so compelling, especially the one of the Illegal Alien, a young Italian woman...

I gave the "Tenement Museum" an average rating because its not really a museum at all. Its a walking tour through a tenement. Did I learn anything on the tour? Of course I did and I'm glad I went. David Koch Theatre offers multiple fares, ballet, modern and other forms of dance. Vivian Beaumont Theater for revivals, plays and other performing arts. Lincoln Restaurant is a 5-Star rating.

You cannot come to New York without experiencing this venue. If you can see a performance at any of the theatres go!
You will have such great choices performed by the BEST companies in the world.
Opera, Ballet, Music,,,,,

Enjoy

We were lucky enough to see The King and I. Amazing show! The walk through Lincoln Centre courtyard was almost as good.

The lobby was inviting and had seats for before the show. My husband is handicapped and they had an elevator. allowing us access to our seats in an easy manner. Plenty of room. Even though we were in the 3rd tier we could see and hear with no problem. the show was outstanding with vibrant colors and fabulous dancers. It...

We went for a classical concert and the seats were comfortable, acoustics fantastic. The staff is very helpful and center very well run. There is a small cafe if you need a quick bite before or after your visit. We stay in midtown at 49th and Lexington and needed to take a cab/F.Y.I.

Wow, what can I say. This venue is great to watch a production such as the King and I. The facilities are well kept and there does not appear to be a bad seat in the house! Our seats were in the second to last row in the orchestra near the sound board and everything was still close by. The...

First time my Teens have seen the Opera, it was very exciting for them - not only the Opera, but, the buildings and the people.

Beautiful! The opera house is impeccably kept. The scenery was gorgeous as were the costumes. A feast for the eyes and ears!

World class art and entertainment. Go for the rich traditions and vibrant history, come back for the fresh, young and sensual, accessible art experience.

title: The Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), New York City
address: 11 West 53rd Street, New York City, NY 10019
review_list:
I'm not even an art lover, but I can appreciate some of the fine pieces here. I'm aware of the famous artists and the famous pieces here didn't disappoint. It's very cool to see them in person and up close. This is a huge museum and you can spend 4 hours here very easily. Take your time and take breaks....


More  



We visited the MOMA this afternoon and had a wonderful visit. Enough amazing art without being overwhelming or feeling like you might be missing something. The curators were very helpful and the shop is fun. A must-see for those visiting NYC!

If you are a fan of modern art or just want to know more, you must visit MOMA. See great masterpieces from Picasso, Dali, Magritte, Duchamp, Miro, Matisse, Monet, and many many more.

Picasso Matisse Van Gogh Warhol. Lots to see here many famous paintings in the collection plus some interesting modern exhibitions. Expensive for a larger family but good on a rainy day.

It was my second time in NY, the first time I had so many things in my to-do-list that I didn't make it to MoMa.-what a mistake! This museum is amazing, with so many incredible pieces of art!

Landed at LGA, rushed to check in and then went to MOMA. It's free late Friday, get your ticket and go to top floor. Slowly work back way to ground. Sure it's packed with people but still very very cool. Not only is there pleasure in seeing great art, there is a nice bookstore of specialty books.

MoMa is a favorite--particularly the collections on levels 4 and 5. Sometimes we enjoy the special exhibits; sometimes we think "Really? That's art?" But it's always interesting. We love the building, too. What an amazing space!

So although I have made it several times and been to the Met and Guggahiem, I had never made it to MOMA before because I thought I didn't like modern art and the building wasnt very distinctive. It gets crowded on Friday nights but well worth the price of admission ($0) for the main exhibits. Check their calendar for special exhibits.

I didn't know Picasso was such a brilliant sculpture. A genius! My wife and I also saw Van Gogh's "Starry Night". The information booth was very helpful. You can buy espresso, Wine, beer and food there
